quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: All mankind love a lover.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The lover of nature is he whose inward and outward senses are still truly adjusted to each other; who has retained the spirit of infancy even into the era of manhood. His intercourse with heaven and earth, becomes part of his daily food. (Nature, Essay)
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: These roses under my window make no reference to former roses or to better ones; they are for what they are; they exist with God to-day. There is no time to them. There is simply the rose; it is perfect in every moment of its existence.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: It is one light which beams out of a thousand stars. It is one soul which animates all men. (The American Scholar)
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The power of Nature predominates over the human will in all works of even the fine arts, in all that respects their material and external circumstances. quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Do not waste yourself in rejection, nor bark against the bad, but chant the beauty of the good.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: We ascribe beauty to that which is simple; which has no superfluous parts; which exactly answers its end. […] It is the most enduring quality, and the most ascending quality.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Beauty without grace is the hook without the bait.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: I have been writing and speaking what were once called novelties, for twenty five or thirty years, & have not now one disciple. Why? Not that what I said was not true; not that it has not found intelligent receivers but because it did not go from any wish in me to bring men to me, but to themselves.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Do not yet see, that, if the single man plant himself indomitably on his instincts, and there abide, the huge world will come round to him.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: All our progress is an unfolding, like the vegetable bud. You have first an instinct, then an opinion, then a knowledge, as the plant has root, bud, and fruit. (Essays: First Series)
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Trust the instinct to the end, though you can render no reason. It is vain to hurry it. By trusting it to the end it shall ripen into truth, and you shall know why you believe.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: To believe your own thought, to believe that what is true for you in your private heart is true for all men, — that is genius.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: A man should learn to detect and watch that gleam of light which flashes across his mind from within, more than the lustre of the firmament of bards and sages. Yet he dismisses without notice his thought, because it is his.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: It is easy to live for others, everybody does. I call on you to live for yourself.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Our distrust is very expensive.

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: What a man does, that he has. What has he to do with hope or fear? In himself is his might. Let him regard no good as solid but that which is in his nature, and which must grow out of him as long as he exists. The goods of fortune may come and go like summer leaves; let him scatter them on every wind as the momentary signs of his infinite productiveness.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Whatever you do, you need courage. Whatever course you decide upon, there is always someone to tell you that you are wrong. There are always difficulties arising that tempt you to believe your critics are right. To map out a course of action and follow it to an end requires some of the same courage that a soldier needs. Peace has its victories, but it takes brave men and women to win them.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Fear is an instructor of great sagacity, and the herald of all revolutions.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: What a new face courage puts on everything!

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: That what we seek we shall find; what we flee from flees from us.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: What we fear doing most is usually what we most need to do.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Whatever games are played with us, we must play no games with ourselves, but deal in our privacy with the last honesty and truth.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The mark of the man of the world is absence of pretension. He does not make a speech; he takes a low business-tone, avoids all brag, is nobody, dresses plainly, promises not at all, performs much, speaks in monosyllables, hugs his fact.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The greatest homage we can pay to truth is to use it.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: As long as a man stands in his own way, everything seems to be in his way.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Happy is the house that shelters a friend.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The only reward of virtue is virtue; the only way to have a friend is to be one.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Friendship should be surrounded with ceremonies and respects, and not crushed into corners. Friendship requires more time than poor busy men can usually command.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The glory of friendship is not the outstretched hand, nor the kindly smile, nor the joy of companionship; it is the spiritual inspiration that comes to one when you discover that someone else believes in you and is willing to trust you with a friendship.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Trust men and they will be true to you; treat them greatly, and they will show themselves great.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: A friend is a person with whom I may be sincere. Before him I may think aloud.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: I am arrived at last in the presence of a man so real and equal that I may drop even those undermost garments of dissimulation, courtesy, and second thought, which men never put off, and may deal with him with the simplicity and wholeness, with which one chemical atom meets another.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The other element of friendship is tenderness. We are holden to men by every sort of tie, by blood, by pride, by fear, by hope, by lucre, by lust, by hate, by admiration, by every circumstance and badge and trifle, but we can scarce believe that so much character can subsist in another as to draw us by love.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Life is short, but there is always time enough for courtesy.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Can another be so blessed, and we so pure, that we can offer him tenderness? When a man becomes dear to me, I have touched the goal of fortune.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Two may talk and one may hear, but three cannot take part in a conversation of the most sincere and searching sort.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Always scorn appearances, and you always may.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The ornament of a house is the friends who frequent it.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: He who has a thousand friends has not a friend to spare, and he who has one enemy will meet him everywhere.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: A friend may well be reckoned the masterpiece of nature.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The highest compact we can make with our fellow is, “Let there be truth between us two forever more”.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Friends seem to be only mirrors to draw out and explain to us ourselves; and that which draws us nearer our fellow man, is, that the deep Heart in one, answers the deep Heart in another, — that we find we have (a common Nature) — one life which runs through all individuals, and which is indeed Divine.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The condition which high friendship demands is ability to do without it.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Our intellectual and active powers increase with our affection. The scholar sits down to write, and all his years of meditation do not furnish him with one good thought or happy expression; but it is necessary to write a letter to a friend, and, forthwith, troops of gentle thoughts invest themselves, on every hand, with chosen words.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: I must feel pride in my friend’s accomplishments as if they were mine, and a property in his virtues. I feel as warmly when he is praised, as the lover when he hears applause of his engaged maiden.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: I do not wish to treat friendships daintily, but with roughest courage. When they are real, they are not glass threads or frost-work, but the solidest thing we know.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: I hate the prostitution of the name of friendship to signify modish and worldly alliances.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Friendship is for aid and comfort through all the relations and passages of life and death.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: It is one of the blessings of old friends that you can afford to be stupid with them.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: It is fit for serene days, and graceful gifts, and country rambles, but also for rough roads and hard fare, shipwreck, poverty, and persecution.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: We are to dignify to each other the daily needs and offices of man’s life, and embellish it by courage, wisdom and unity.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: It should never fall into something usual and settled, but should be alert and inventive, and add rhyme and reason to what was drudgery.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Friendship demands a religious treatment. We talk of choosing our friends, but friends are self-elected. Reverence is a great part of it.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The essence of friendship is entireness, a total magnanimity and trust.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Other men are lenses through which we read our own minds. (Representative Men)
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Let your greatness educate the crude and cold companion.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Men are better than their theology.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Let us be silent, that we may hear the whisper of God.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: God enters by a private door into every individual.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Make your own Bible. Select and collect all the words and sentences that in all your readings have been to you like the blast of a trumpet.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The religion of one age is the literary entertainment of the next.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The progress of religion is steadily to its identity with morals. Strength enters just as much as the moral element prevails.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The god of the cannibals will be a cannibal, of the crusaders a crusader, and of the merchants a merchant.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The religion that is afraid of science dishonors God and commits suicide.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: In the matter of religion, people eagerly fasten their eyes on the difference between their own creed and yours; whilst the charm of the study is in finding the agreements and identities in all the religions of humanity.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: A sect or party is an elegant incognito devised to save a man from the vexation of thinking.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: In how many churches, by how many prophets, tell me, is man made sensible that he is an infinite Soul; that the earth and heavens are passing into his mind; that he is drinking forever the soul of God?
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Religion is to do right. It is to love, it is to serve, it is to think, it is to be humble.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: When a man lives with God, his voice shall be as sweet as the murmur of the brook and the rustle of the corn.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: God offers to every mind its choice between truth and repose.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: All I have seen teaches me to trust the creator for all I have not seen.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The faith that stands on authority is not faith.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The less government we have, the better — the fewer laws, and the less confided power.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Society everywhere is in conspiracy against the manhood of everyone of its members.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: A nation never falls but by suicide.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Man exists for his own sake and not to add a laborer to the state.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The two parties which divide the state, the party of Conservatism and that of Innovation, are very old, and have disputed the possession of the world ever since it was made.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: These rabble at Washington … see, against the unanimous expression of the people, how much a little well-directed effrontery can achieve, how much crime the people will bear, and they proceed from step to step…
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Conservatism stands on man’s confessed limitations; reform on his indisputable infinitude; conservatism on circumstance; liberalism on power; one goes to make an adroit member of the social frame; the other to postpone all things to the man himself; conservatism is debonnair and social; reform is individual and imperious.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Reform is affirmative, conservatism negative; conservatism goes for comfort, reform for truth.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Conservatism is more candid to behold another’s worth; reform more disposed to maintain and increase its own.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Conservatism makes no poetry, breathes no prayer, has no invention; it is all memory. Reform has no gratitude, no prudence, no husbandry.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: When a whole nation is roaring Patriotism at the top of its voice, I am fain to explore the cleanness of its hands and the purity of its heart.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The true test of civilization is, not the census, nor the size of the cities, nor the crops – no, but the kind of man the country turns out.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: From Washington, proverbially ‘the city of distances,’ through all its cities, states, and territories, it is a country of beginnings, of projects, of designs, and expectations.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Those who stay away from the election think that one vote will do no good: ‘Tis but one step more to think one vote will do no harm.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: There is always a certain meanness in the argument of conservatism, joined with a certain superiority in its fact.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: These are the voices which we hear in solitude, but they grow faint and inaudible as we enter into the world.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Society is a wave. The wave moves onward, but the water of which it is composed does not. (Self-Reliance and Other Essays)
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: All men plume themselves on the improvement of society, and no man improves.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: With the past, I have nothing to do; nor with the future. I live now.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Let us leave hurry to slaves.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Time dissipates to shining ether the solid angularity of facts.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Speak your latent conviction, and it shall be the universal sense; for the inmost in due time becomes the outmost, — and our first thought is rendered back to us by the trumpets of the Last Judgment. (Self-Reliance and Other Essays)
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: A man builds a fine house; and now he has a master, and a task for life: he is to furnish, watch, show it, and keep it in repair, the rest of his days.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Alcohol, hashish, prussic acid, strychnine are weak dilutions. The surest poison is time.

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Life is not so short but that there is always time enough for courtesy. (Letters and Social Aims)
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Who hears me, who understands me, becomes mine, a possession for all time.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Nature is methodical, and doeth her work well. Time is never to be hurried.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The imagination and the senses cannot be gratified at the same time.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Manners require time, and nothing is more vulgar than haste.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: This day is all that is good and fair. It is too dear, with its hopes and invitations, to waste a moment on the yesterdays.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Guard well your spare moments. They are like uncut diamonds. Discard them and their value will never be known. Improve them and they will become the brightest gems in a useful life.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: This time, like all times, is a very good one, if we but know what to do with it.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The sum of wisdom is that time is never lost that is devoted to work.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Today is a king in disguise.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Grow angry slowly – there’s plenty of time.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Finish each day before you begin the next, and interpose a solid wall of sleep between the two. This you cannot do without temperance.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Tobacco, coffee, alcohol, hashish, prussic acid, strychnine, are weak dilutions. The surest poison is time.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: So much of our time is spent in preparation, so much in routine, and so much in retrospect, that the amount of each person’s genius is confined to a very few hours.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: A moment is a concentrated eternity.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: What would be the use of immortality to a person who cannot use well a half an hour?
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Live in the sunshine, swim the sea, drink the wild air.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Health is the first muse, and sleep is the condition to produce it.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Give me health and a day, and I will make the pomp of emperors ridiculous. (Nature, Essay)
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The imagination is not a talent of some men but is the health of every man.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Few people know how to take a walk. The qualifications are endurance, plain clothes, old shoes, an eye for nature, good humor, vast curiosity, good speech, good silence and nothing too much.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The one thing in the world, of value, is the active soul. (The American Scholar)
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Health is the condition of wisdom, and the sign is cheerfulness – an open and noble temper.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: When I go into the garden with a spade, and dig a bed, I feel such an exhilaration and health that I discover that I have been defrauding myself all this time in letting others do for me what I should have done with my own hands.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Sickness is poor-spirited, and cannot serve anyone; it must husband its resources to live. But health or fullness answers its own ends, and has to spare, runs over, and inundates the neighborhoods and creeks of other men’s necessities.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: We forget ourselves and our destinies in health, and the chief use of temporary sickness is to remind us of these concerns.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Prudence is the virtue of the senses. […] It is content to seek health of body by complying with physical conditions, and health of mind by the laws of the intellect.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: I will say, get health. No labor, pains, temperance, poverty, nor exercise, that can gain it, must be grudged.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The best part of health is fine disposition. It is more essential than talent, even in the works of talent.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Whenever you are sincerely pleased, you are nourished. The joy of the spirit indicates its strength. All healthy things are sweet-tempered.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Intellectual tasting of life will not supersede muscular activity.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: We don’t grow old. When we cease to grow, we become old.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: What is true anywhere is true everywhere.

quotes.text: Though we travel the world over to find the beautiful, we must carry it with us, or we find it not. (The Essays of )
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Travelling is a fool’s paradise. Our first journeys discover to us the indifference of places.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: At home I dream that at Naples, at Rome, I can be intoxicated with beauty, and lose my sadness. I pack my trunk, embrace my friends, embark on the sea, and at last wake up in Naples, and there beside me is the stern fact, the sad self, unrelenting, identical, that I fled from. I seek the Vatican, and the palaces. I affect to be intoxicated with sights and suggestions, but I am not intoxicated. My giant goes with me wherever I go.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The most advanced nations are always those who navigate the most.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: I am not much an advocate for traveling, and I observe that men run away to other countries because they are not good in their own, and run back to their own because they pass for nothing in the new places. For the most part, only the light characters travel.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: For the most part, only the light characters travel. Who are you that have no task to keep you at home?
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: No man should travel until he has learned the language of the country he visits. Otherwise he voluntarily makes himself a great baby – so helpless and so ridiculous.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Everything good is on the highway.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: It is for want of self-culture that the superstition of travelling, whose idols are Italy, England, Egypt, retains its fascination for all educated Americans.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: Our minds travel when our bodies are forced to stay at home.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The soul is no traveler; the wise man stays at home, and when his necessities, his duties, on any occasion call him from his house, or into foreign lands, he is at home still.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: I have no churlish objection to the circumnavigation of the globe, for the purposes of art, of study, and benevolence, so that the man is first domesticated, or does not go abroad with the hope of finding somewhat greater than he knows.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: He who travels to be amused, or to get somewhat which he does not carry, travels away from himself, and grows old even in youth among old things.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The antidotes against this organic egotism, are, the range and variety of attractions, as gained by acquaintance with the world, with men of merit, with classes of society, with travel, with eminent persons, and with the high resources of philosophy, art, and religion: books, travel, society, solitude.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: He that does not fill a place at home, cannot abroad. He only goes there to hide his insignificance in a larger crowd.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: You do not think you will find anything there which you have not seen at home? The stuff of all countries is just the same.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The phrase ‘to know the world,’ or to travel, is synonymous with all men’s ideas of advantage and superiority. No doubt, to a man of sense, travel offers advantages.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quotes.text: The uses of travel are occasional, and short; but the best fruit it finds, when it finds it, is conversation; and this is a main function of life.
quotes.author: Ralph Waldo Emerson
